description: Inherited from Middle English worstede, worsted, from Worstede (now Worstead; Old English *Wurϸestede), a town in Norfolk, England.

entries.meaning: (textiles) Yarn made from long strands of wool.
examples: An old set-stitched chair, valanced and fringed around with party-coloured worsted bobs, stood at the bed’s head opposite to the side where my father’s head reclined.

entries.meaning: The fine, smooth fabric made from such wool yarn.

description: Participle adjective of the verb worst.

adjectives.description: worsted (comparative more worsted, superlative most worsted)

examples: The army was worsted in battle.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of worst
